awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  A Dyadic and Dynamic Model of Supportive Conversations as Interpersonal Emotion Regulation
awd_abstract_narration:
Decades of research shows that people benefit from social support.  Those with richer social networks experience lower rates of disease, live longer lives, and enjoy better mental health.  Even though the benefits of supportive relationships are well established, less is known about how and why those outcomes occur.  This project focuses on common stressful events that people experience every day, and the conversations people have with others to cope with those events.  It is expected that conversations about everyday stressors help people think and feel differently about their problems, which may help account for the short- and long-term health benefits so commonly found.  This project develops a new method for the coding and analysis of conversations about personal problems.  Tools will be developed to train laypersons and professionals in how to be most helpful in supportive conversations, ultimately benefiting people's health and well-being.

This project uses data from four previously conducted studies in which 461 people disclosed a personal stressor to a stranger, friend, or dating partner.  The project analyzes the discloser's reactions to the partner's messages by examining the ways in which the discloser expresses thoughts and feelings through language.  Videotapes and transcripts of these conversations allow detailed coding of every utterance of the partner's responses.  The coding system is capable of distinguishing among many different statements and expressions that commonly occur in such conversations.  Detailed analyses of these conversations will illuminate the turn-to-turn effects of supportive messages on a distressed person's thoughts and feelings.  The analyses will also clarify how dynamics within conversations influence the distressed person's thoughts and emotions.  This project will contribute to future research aimed at developing machine-coding systems for categorizing and quantifying aspects of enacted social support, while also compiling data-analytical tools that will enable researchers to investigate the dynamics of dyadic interaction more generally.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

NSF Project Outcome Report
Award Title: Collaborative Research: A Dyadic and Dynamic Model of Supportive Conversations as Interpersonal Emotion Regulation
Grant No.: 1749454 (Solomon), 1749474 (Bodie), 1749255 (Jones)

Grant Period: 05/2018 to 05/2022

Principal Investigators: Denise Solomon, Graham Bodie, Susanne Jones

Social support is crucial in times of stress. For many, engaging with others in conversation is a helpful means of regulating emotions and coping with problems. But, not all conversations are helpful. When we engage a listener?s help in re-evaluating a stressful event, the interpersonal dynamics at play can facilitate coping or they can make things worse. The overall goal of this project was to examine the process of interpersonal emotion regulation as it occurs over the course of supportive conversations and, in turn, influences emotions. By focusing on the dynamics that unfold as listeners and disclosers contribute to conversations about stressful events, we address key limitations in prior research on social support that typically examines messages in isolation or ignores the content of conversations altogether. In particular, our project addressed four goals:

First, we showcased the efficacy of utilizing archived data to test new hypotheses at a substantially reduced cost (see NSF 1238599). We leveraged four previously conducted laboratory observation studies providing data on a total of 461 conversations. New coding and analyses of these data enabled us to adapt them to our purpose. All data sets involve conversations in which one person discusses a stressor with a partner. The four studies vary in type of problem (naturally occurring vs. induced in the lab), the specific instructions provided to the support providers, the relationship between the support provider and recipient (strangers, friends, dating partners), and the recipients? emotion measurements (video-assisted recall vs. linguistic analysis). Both the similarities and differences across these studies advanced the aims of the project.

Second, we advanced a model that locates the emotion regulation function of support in the turn-by-turn dynamics of conversations, and we tested whether specific conversational patterns influence outcomes, such as emotional improvement. We achieved this goal by identifying six speaking turn types that characterize supportive conversations: asking questions, acknowledging partner contributions, offering advice, as well as using hedged disclosures, elaborations, and reflections. Hedged disclosures contain actual disclosures as well as verbal fillers (e.g., I mean, you know) that signal the speaker?s hesitation to fully process or accept a certain perspective, which might be an important step toward emotional change. Elaborations and reflections are important ways to offer support because they contain extended explanations on the part of the supportive listener, which not only acknowledges the stressed discloser?s experiences but also tries to frame these experiences in a new light. We also found that disclosers tended to use elaborations throughout a conversation, while listeners tended to reflect a lot more toward the end of a conversation. Listeners also ask more questions and use more acknowledgments at the beginning of a conversation.

Third, we developed a comprehensive methodological process for intensive repeated categorical data analysis, which forms the foundation of studying turn-by-turn conversation dynamics. There are a host of sequential data analytical procedures; however, these procedures require data to be continuous [e.g., assessing conversational quality on a scale from 1 (low) to 7 (high)] and synchronously measured (e.g., both conversation partners provide ratings or are rated at the same time points). There are virtually no procedures that allow scholars to analyze asynchronous categorical repeated measures (e.g., a discloser elaboration speaking turn, followed by a listener question, and then followed by a discloser reflection turn). To address the lack of existing methods, we developed the dynamic dyadic systems (DDS) approach to studying conversation dynamics. Our DDS approach consists of five layers of analysis that examine conversation dynamics at different levels (e.g., turn pairs, long sequences of turns) and we published a paper that outlines each of these layers (Solomon et al., 2021). Scholars can use each of the five layers or any one layer to make sense of conversation dynamics. These layers are also modality-agnostic and can be used for any kind of data set in which sequences of categorically coded behaviors exchanged between partners in a dyad are recorded, including verbal messages, nonverbal cues, emotional responses, among others.

Finally, we disseminated our newly designed DDS process across a host of disciplines. In addition to publishing a theoretical paper that outlines the data analytic process (Solomon et al., 2021), we also launched a website that features tutorials for the methods we use in our DDS approach, and we held a workshop at the foremost conference in communication studies in 2021.
